column5: Members and friends of @LondonFuturists are invited to take part in the World Futures Day online facilitated futures-focused discussion on 1st March, hosted by the @MillenniumProj with support from a range of partners https://t.co/CfWE6h6Oql https://t.co/9lK1mYhj7D

@jrbarrat The SENS Board announcement I posted came out many months *after* that Fierce Biotech article. I'm not denying that the reported (and partially disputed) "harassment" was poor judgement. But the word you used was "assault". No investigation supported such a claim.
Immense tensions between the internal advocates of responsible AI and those keen to "just integrate AI" asap. Worrying, but not surprising

Peter also shares some intriguing background behind his novels "Host", "Perfect People", and "Possession", and mentions a 1990 book that had a big impact on him: "Great Mambo Chicken and the Transhuman Condition"
https://t.co/0MmhcmrZ1G

@jrbarrat That smoke cleared some time ago. Even AdeG's critics on the Board of SENS noted, for example, that "Dr. de Grey is not a sexual predator". It's a real shame that working relationships broke down so badly, but important new work now takes place at LEVF https://t.co/ZfjFDDOnZH

Peter James, best-selling crime writer, has produced a remarkable 19 consecutive Sunday Times Number One bestsellers. In the latest @LondonFuturists Podcast episode, he talks about his passion for the future and his appreciation of transhumanism https://t.co/0MmhcmrZ1G https://t.co/j0xOdPwwaU

And:  How does this project fit into a broader vision for the attainment, by humans, of the Longevity Escape Velocity?
https://t.co/JKF4uVLhtv

This project is the first of multiple planned ambitious LEVF studies on mouse longevity using a combination of interventions.
Likely to be covered include in this Salon:
What is the thinking behind the project? How is it being structured? What range of outcomes might be expected?

This Sunday, at 9pm UK time, the USTP's Virtual Enlightenment Salon will feature Dr. Aubrey de Grey discussing the flagship project of the new Longevity Escape Velocity Foundation (LEV Foundation): Robust Mouse Rejuvenation Study 1
https://t.co/JKF4uVLhtv
"The major general committed suicide"

@tszzl Sometimes it's best to start a conversation from a place the audience already understands. Then add in the larger elements when their minds have already partially glimpsed the scale of what's ahead
Not just in 1966. Many "experts" made similar predictions well into the 1990s
@nearyd Human history continued after 1914-1918 and again after 1939-1945. The possibility is that human history might come to an end at some point in the next few decades. Perhaps suddenly
This scenario isn’t entirely out of the question

@peterevoss I have a half-written blog in which I reconsider the question of superintelligence and superethics. I need to find the time to finish it :-o

I agree that, as AI advances, it will provide us with some potential solutions to existing AI safety questions. Plus more complications
After trying many deluded policies regarding relations with the EU, there's not much left for the UK government to try, except some more sensible ones
On this occasion, the presentations will be in English.

Live streaming at 4pm UK time (5pm Madrid time) today - three speakers providing an update on the latest cryopreservation capabilities around the world (USA, Germany, Australia). With audience Q&A. Hosted by José @cordeiro at Madrid Singularity https://t.co/jE6y191Tmi
@IntuitMachine @dilgreen That's the question I approach in the section "An option to control superintelligent AI" in this blog post from the end of last year https://t.co/vJyILoeC12

@IntuitMachine @dilgreen The vital question for me is: how do we avoid AI systems developing a sense of agency, even if we haven't included any agency in our design? Agency might emerge, contrary to our intention

@dilgreen @IntuitMachine It sounds like you're speculating about how many angels can dance on the edge of a pinprick.

My concern is that an AGI toddler, with capabilities that are hard to understand but initially seem impressive, jumps into a metaphorical military tank and mows us all down

@WallfacerAG Once this debate is organised, I'll be happy to share news of it within the @LondonFuturists community, to give it a larger audience.

Here's my own argument that fast-changing hard-to-understand AI systems pose a catastrophic if not an existential risk https://t.co/YPji14JLng

The issue: Large Language Models "are inexplicably good at carrying out tasks that they haven’t been specifically trained to perform". It's as if we showed a young human toddler how to turn the steering wheel of a toy car, and he jumped into a military tank and drove that around
This headline seems like a joke, but it isn't: "Scientists Made a Mind-Bending Discovery About How AI Actually Works" https://t.co/TxdadUUdyQ
This is a better analysis than "progress in AI is basically a smooth exponential curve"

@litarchivist I hope that the disease that kills you won't deprive you of the ability to enjoy eating delicious food. In many occasions, dementia or stroke or cancer destroys such an ability. Such deaths are rarely the "happy" ones you anticipate
@Korstanje Agreed, before involving the EU in any new discussions, UK politicians need to reach a stronger consensus than 52:48 on a way forward with agreements with the EU
An encouraging sign of some grown-up politics - "Revealed: secret cross-party summit held to confront failings of Brexit" https://t.co/uU8iSez6Ls

4) Your opinions wanted, about aging, life extension, death;
5) Holiday plans this August: Dublin?
6) Even God Herself (Humanity Unshackled)
https://t.co/4bQwphkKdf
Expect more conservatives to become fans of proportional representation

"Anti-ageing scientists extend lifespan of oldest living lab rat." One independent reviewer comments: "One swallow does not make a summer. But I believe the results because several complementary studies support them" https://t.co/DvWfk9Uxgg
AI-powered search could be doubly disruptive for Google
@IntuitMachine Also transformers have enabled more reliable self-supervised learning, so more powerful models can be created without being so dependent on human annotation of the training data

@IntuitMachine I've just enjoyed re-reading that article. This bit stood out for me: "Deep Learning is the wheel of cognition. Just as the wheel enabled more effective transportation, so will Deep Learning achieve effective artificial intelligence."

@dilgreen @IntuitMachine @Abebab I don't point to any single software engineer as having a uniquely privileged insight. I pointed to Carmack as having ONE set of ideas that deserve more attention.

I've pointed in a similar way several times over the years to research by @IntuitMachine eg https://t.co/fgR4C69At2

Today, London Futurists Podcast reached the milestone of 25 episodes. We have released a new episode every week since the beginning of Sept. Each month's downloads significantly exceed the previous month's. Which episodes did *you* like the best so far? https://t.co/qnsaMsod6E
@dilgreen Also see the work of Dileep George https://t.co/5V2iBoytBq
@dilgreen You should also take a look at the work of Jeff Hawkins, as described in his book "A Thousand Brains: A New Theory of Intelligence" https://t.co/jmYLNy1hPn

@dilgreen I share your strong apprehension about "moving fast and breaking things". However, compared to you, I see much more openness in AI communities to insights from neuroscience: companies like DeepMind have hired lots of neuroscience PhDs (including Demis Hassabis himself)

"Curing aging: $100B?" - in the latest @LondonFuturists Podcast episode, Dr Andrew Steele (@statto) gives a wonderfully clear explanation of how we humans might become able to "be more tortoise", "getting older without getting old" https://t.co/yQbS2UCT84

@dilgreen An even better example would be Charles Lindberg, the aviator, whose outside perspective (plus a personal tragedy experienced by his sister-in-law) led him to conceive of a mechanical heart replacement, against the opinions of contemporary medical doctors https://t.co/6GZeKg1azp
@dilgreen It's like asking a pair of brilliant bicycle engineers about the development of a heavier-than-air powered aircraft, instead of trusting lots of university professors ;-)
@GzzztBrain @jacyanthis For an intro to some of possibilities of machine sentience, see this recording of a recent webinar featuring Jacy at London Futurists https://t.co/TL8qvSCI5V

@GzzztBrain But since you asked, I'll point to the Sentience Institute, headed by @JacyAnthis, which is doing fine work in understanding (and advocacy in support of) sentience in all its splendid varieties, both biological and synthetic https://t.co/XYj0VUWbCv

@GzzztBrain Ah, "sentience". That's not what I've been discussing. The existential risk (and enormous opportunity) is when AI systems become more capable than humans in understanding and manipulating the environment (and the other lifeforms it contains). That's AGI. No need for sentience

@GzzztBrain Darren, Now you're sounding more and more like the learned critics who had so many arguments, 1900-1903, as to why supposedly foolish tinkerers like the Wright brothers could never manage to get their heavier-than-air devices off the ground and pilot them safely ;-)

@GzzztBrain You're describing the AI systems prior to the recent revolutions of transformers and generative diffusion. Now with self-supervised learning systems, much more intelligence *does* arise from scanning large datasets. See e.g. https://t.co/iSf4zWP3EZ
@JimRice1111 @BartenOtto There's also this: Carmack's reply to the question, "What is the mission of Keen Technologies?" https://t.co/zDr8B41eb6

@JimRice1111 Indeed there are good reasons to worry. @BartenOtto has drawn my attention to other remarks by Carmack, in which, when asked about "AI ethics things", he replied "I really stay away from any of those discussions or even really thinking about it" https://t.co/8jVsnWWfn3

@GzzztBrain It's not always necessary to fully understand the underlying science before you can engineer something. Steam engines were pretty effective even before the laws of thermodynamics were established. Present-day AI systems often achieve a lot more than their designers expected

@GzzztBrain Sure, the code only results in general intelligence due to interactions with the environment. In the case of AI, these interactions include scanning vast data sources and feedback from observers (human and/or narrow AIs, both of them in supervisory roles)
@Jobob_80 Collaboration and cross-fertilisation of ideas: absolutely!

@catlaughing @Jobob_80 Asking "is this AI really intelligent" is a bit like asking "does this submarine really swim" or "does this airplane really fly". The more important question is what these systems are likely to do in the world - both the good outcomes and the potentially horrendous outcomes

@catlaughing @Jobob_80 A lot of research into AI (and AGI) is driven pragmatically. It's not trying to exactly mirror features of the human mind. It's trying to find ways for applications to improve all kinds of work tasks, in every field of work (science, medicine, education, driving, creativity...)

@Jobob_80 The most significant steps forward with AI will almost certainly involve carefully orchestrated *combinations* of different modules (including intuition engines). See for example this analysis by Gary Marcus of Meta AI’s Diplomacy-winning Cicero AI https://t.co/M8McgmBzAq

@Jobob_80 Second, software engineering *does* have a key role to play in the creation of AGI, alongside some ML and data mining. The latter provides the equivalent of a profound intuition engine, but there's more to general intelligence than scaling up an intuition engine
@Jobob_80 Several episodes of London Futurists Podcast cover this second big bang. E.g. this one with Alessandro Curioni of IBM https://t.co/iSf4zWP3EZ

@Jobob_80 I see things differently, in two key aspects.
1) Whereas data generally had to be manually prepared for use by ML systems prior to around 2019, the revolution of the second AI big bang enabled much greater self-supervised learning (via transformers, diffusion models, etc)
@ProfSteveFuller I promoted it because his views on AGI are interestingly different from that of many other people who are also thinking about how to create AGI.
@pattyneta I've seen lots of people asking online for that list, but no-one has posted it yet - see e.g. the replies to this https://t.co/IFSzHruWY1

@ProfSteveFuller On the contrary, Carmack *isn't* trying to raise any additional funds at this time:

"I’m actually not spending much money right now. I raised $20 million, but I’m thinking that this is a decade-long task where I don’t want to burn through $20 million in the next two years"

@ProfSteveFuller What do you think, Steve, about the other things Carmack said in that interview (including his justifications, in broad terms, for the figures quoted)?
https://t.co/0QVXNMkw8y

Carmack's estimate for whether he, personally, might be the person to create AGI: "I think I’ve got a couple percent chance of doing this, and it’s worth trillions, that’s not a bad bet"

For the full interview see https://t.co/0QVXNMkw8y
So Carmack says: "I’m trying to marry together some of these fields that are distinct, that have what I feel are pieces of the AGI algorithm"
Finally, one thing that today's much more powerful hardware (and accompanying software tools support) makes possible is the quick investigation of combinations of individual ideas

Another supportive argument he offers is that there are many promising ideas that were looked at as long ago as the 1970s, 80s, and 90s, which were dropped at that time because they didn't work, but which could take a new lease of life with the extra hardware available nowadays
That even makes it possible that "the programming for AGI is going to be something that one person could write"

One argument Carmack offers for these conclusions is that the software code needed for AGI probably isn't that huge. After all, the amount of instructions in DNA that enables general intelligence in humans is "like 40 megabytes... not all that much code"
As for reaching AGI by 2050: "And if you go up to, say, 2050, I’ve got it at like a 95% chance"

That's why it's worth paying attention to this recent interview that John Carmack gave, in which he estimates "maybe a 60% chance... we’ll have clear signs of life in 2030 of artificial general intelligence" https://t.co/0QVXNMkw8y

If you ask a good software engineer who they respect as being even better at the discipline than themselves, and then keep repeating the process, one of the "apex" engineers at the top of the chain of respect is probably John Carmack. That's why his views on AGI are significant

@Driigun1 @cailinmeister There you go again with this extraordinary "killing people" infatuation of yours.

To prevent any more hysteria, I'm blocking this conversation. Goodbye

@Driigun1 @cailinmeister The transition will involve stages. Some countries already generate the majority of their electricity from non-fossil fuel sources. The provision of other green energy sources (personally I include nuclear) can and must be accelerated. Your hysterical scaremongering is ill-judged

@Driigun1 @cailinmeister Blimey. No one is proposing "to actively kill people now". The proposal is to accelerate a transition from an economy based on polluting energy to an economy based on green energy. There will be plenty of flourishing in the latter - vibrant green growth. No "active killing"

@Driigun1 @cailinmeister How much "scientific certainty" do you think is needed? If there's only a 10% chance that an airliner might fall out of the sky over the Atlantic, will you board it? Are you comfortable with a 10% chance that continued emissions of GHGs will push the climate over a tipping point?

@Driigun1 @cailinmeister Dear climate change denier: How do you respond to the extensive evidence (covered in the research quoted by the speaker in yesterday's webinar) that many of scientists who denied links between human activity and climate change also used similar methods to deny (1/2)
@adam_dorr @JeffLadish @ESYudkowsky @sama @OpenAI The road to AI catastrophe is paved with good intentions

In case you missed it - or want to re-watch some of the deeply important ideas covered in this webinar - the recording is now available of "The spread of disinformation" featuring Cailin O'Connor (@cailinmeister) https://t.co/vVFTihCPTO

@eugediana @cccalum The word "Humanity+" indicates the vision: building on and enhancing the best aspects of human nature, whilst overcoming or transcending the worst aspects. It will indeed be a radical evolution, but it won't necessarily reject all aspects of biology
The results of this investigation deserve lots more attention: Politicians throughout Europe who allowed themselves to be bribed and manipuated into actions supporting Putin

@eugediana @cccalum Transhumanism itself is pragmatic and open-minded. The solutions it prefers are whatever works best (taking into account all externalities). Also relevant: the transhumanist advocacy of "morphological freedom"
Hi @meetup_support - are you the right people to look into this? This misbehaviour is still happening. The app's bungled mishandling of these links in messages is a real annoyance
It's time to think through the possible consequences of forthcoming big changes in UK politics

"Overcoming limitations" - @NatashaVitaMore shares her observations on how transhumanism has evolved over the decades, and reflects on the successes and challenges of her work in building the movement: the latest @LondonFuturists Podcast episode https://t.co/h4guWCX1py
In this case, would the parliamentary leader of the SNP MPs become the Leader of the Opposition?

I've prepared my slides "Artificial Intelligence and options for a sustainable future" for the @AIPATurkey #WeAreRunningToTheFuture online event, where I'll be speaking on 11th Feb https://t.co/OzoIJuuOaE https://t.co/wLbzqcoXio
I'll be watching this, and offering occasional comments
This will be a welcome development!

Cutting to the chase: "What are the main reasons why misinformation spreads?"
These are all significant mechanisms, but I anticipate that our speaker on Saturday, Cailin O'Connor, will highlight additional important perspectives re transmisson & prevention https://t.co/L9xRP7Q2Pm https://t.co/a6po87LWcS
Next, here's ChatGPT's response to "What are specific examples of deadly misinformation?" https://t.co/3m5Keheepf

Looking ahead to the _next_ webinar, on "How misinformation spreads", I wondered about examples of the worst kind of misinformation. So I asked ChatGPT "Which medical theories turned out to be wrong, and caused lots of harm to patients?" Once again, the answer was impressive https://t.co/oCFIFsz6Cw
@rzeta0 @LondonFuturists Tariq - Can I interest you in being a guest in a forthcoming webinar presenting _your_ recommendations for how AI should best be governed? Or who else would you recommend?

@rzeta0 @LondonFuturists Regarding the risks of complex algorithms, his answer was be that regulation within each vertical industry should be sufficient. However, personally I'm with you on that point: some types of algorithms can be identified as potentially hugely dangerous across many industries

@rzeta0 @LondonFuturists A second example was in his own university department. A tool that was useful to students, to predict their grades based on performance in early assignments, was shut down, due to concerns that it violated some data privacy regulations of the GDPR

@rzeta0 @LondonFuturists Thanks for the feedback. On how regulation can damage innovation, consider his example that some small companies producing medical devices may decide to cease trading rather than undertake what seems to them an overly time-consuming recertification process for existing devices

The EU AI Act is coming soon. But do we need it? Will it do more harm than good? How well do its political supporters understand the issues involved? The recording of yesterday's @LondonFuturists webinar featuring Patrick Glauner is now available https://t.co/In6xOOiORy
@danfaggella That's a scenario Patrick Glauner highlighted in the webinar that has just finished (the recording should be online some time tomorrow morning)

As a follow-up, I tried a more open-ended question: "What are the most likely consequences, in five years time, of the EU AI Act?"
ChatGPT gave an upbeat answer: https://t.co/0DPqXJDN5M

@TomKBowman @cccalum However, I'm told that the definitive exploration of reasons and options for alien monitoring the Earth is in the "Existence" novel by @DavidBrin - which I hope to find time to read shortly! https://t.co/mDNsjfKwV7

@TomKBowman @cccalum This talk looks at one concern such aliens might have. The next question is the best way for them to keep watch on us. A system with some local monitoring may prove to be most effective, given the limitations of communications to the speed of light https://t.co/x6QYFTrs2e

Alien civilisations, much wiser than us, may monitor us in case our high-energy physics experiments, not at CERN but at a future CERN++, unintentionally rupture the galactic spacetime continuum. I explored that idea in this #TransVision2021 talk in Madrid  https://t.co/6LEGHhvz3x
@mmitchell_ai Laid off, or moved on by their own choice?
This is a remarkable obituary

I asked ChatGPT "What are the pros and cons of the EU AI Act?" The answer it gave provides a useful context for today's @LondonFuturists webinar featuring Professor Patrick Glauner, https://t.co/0uoY9RqjCS https://t.co/Uhz4xfoOdo

My hunch is that this is a bug in the @Meetup app. (Perhaps a relatively new bug?) If that app cannot handle a particular link, it shouldn't drop the ball. The link in question should be forwarded on to the web browser, which can handle it fine

The problem is if I include a link in my message, the link is converted to redirect via a https://t.co/h9DgAwqcfx prefix. When my email is received on Android, people can't follow that link, since the @Meetup app grabs it and fails to handle it, oops

Here's a nasty problem I've noticed with people receiving emails sent from the "Contact Members" feature of Meetup. The problem occurs for members using their mobile devices. I'm not sure how long the problem has existed. Are you aware of this, @meetup_support?

@jodypm_dev @BohoWellness One reason people have been shortening their AGI timelines is because they see new AI systems with capabilities that weren't expected for many years into the future. One place this is discussed is in this podcast episode https://t.co/FI2mLkgR1n
We humans are doing some mind-blowing things

@DemonSynth Agreed!

Here's the cross disciplinary educational syllabus that I'm in the process of building (as a cross-disciplinary effort...) https://t.co/WostDQxCPl
Emergence. It's the concept everyone will be talking about in 2023

@amolitor99 Oh, paperclips. Which I didn't mention. They spoil far too many conversations these days. Instead, there is a set of more tangible threats of catastrophic outcomes from the deployment of fast-changing AI that operates beyond human comprehension https://t.co/DhAWnDqCwp
@amolitor99 By the same analysis, submarines don't swim, and airplanes don't fly. But that doesn't mean submarines and airplanes will have little consequence in the world

@amolitor99 You do realise that many military leaders want to enable AI control of some weapons systems without humans in the loop, don't you? Such as swarms of fast-manoeuvering drones. Or even fighter airplanes. This is no armchair discussion

@amolitor99 That brings us to the most important point. Ai systems can cause tremendous damage in the world even without having the same kind of cognition as humans. (That's why some people suggest we should speak of the risk of transformative AI rather than the risk of AGI)

@amolitor99 LLMs have taken even their creators by surprise by many of the things they do. Combination approaches such as in Meta's Diplomacy-winning Cicero AI demonstrate wider skills. New combinations are producing new results almost every day https://t.co/FI2mLkgR1n

@amolitor99 Hofstadter has a track record of over-estimating the complexity of human intelligence. His assumptions of what would be needed for an AI to create soul-tingling music were proved utterly wrong over 20 years ago (Hanbah Fry hsd a chapter on this in her "Hello World" book)

@amolitor99 It's worth reflecting on the arguments raised around 1903 that heavier than air powered flight was, at best, a far-off possibility. These sceptics (and there were many) were no fools. They were just misled by their own lack of knowledge. (See chapter 3 of https://t.co/KOctdFP7mD)
@Nielo_Gan The most likely cause of AGI not being created by 2060 is if human civilisation self-destructs beforehand https://t.co/7GWp3BhZ9n
How well-intentioned good communicators get sucked down the rabbit hole, step by step
@amolitor99 How can you be sure "we're nowhere remotely near an AGI"? Do you understand general intelligence well enough to be sure no AI development team might stumble onto it partly by accident?
Yes, I've been in too many conversations where people make similarly contorted attempts to deny the likelihood of AGI

"A few months ago, FT Alphaville thought it might be fun to host a Mastodon server. Boy, were we wrong! It is therefore with relief & regret that we announce the shutdown of Alphaville Club, this blog’s completely unofficial home on the Fediverse" https://t.co/ZvFNxQImRb

@Michael05156007 It looks like this analyses *one* way in which an AI system might cause catastrophic harm. However, it doesn't address my concern, which is that there are *multiple* ways that advanced AI systems could cause catastrophic harm https://t.co/DhAWnDqCwp
@cccalum @DavidBrin Some of the MPs asked pretty good questions regarding AI. I was just disappointed that I wasn't in the room providing (in some cases) better answers :-)
@Michael05156007 If you have written up your solution somewhere, Michael, I'll be happy to take a look

@CompilersJay That's a good question, as Manish Patel indicated in his longer remarks. One idea is that an AI can make it easier to analyse the data - to spot patterns which humans had previously failed to notice. Also AIs can investigate suggestions from humans regarding potential biases

To close this thread, here's one final link, to another discussion on (among various related topics) how to manage the risks of AI systems that exceed human understanding and control. This time from esteemed scientist and award-winning writer @DavidBrin https://t.co/X7mgCRo9fs

The committee meeting has now ended, but is available to watch on replay. My apologies for all cases of inadvertent misattribution or distortions in my hastily typed thread of comments above! https://t.co/iQouB7ire4

Katherine Fletcher MP, who was a software developer in a past life, recommends focus on "outcome based approaches" - with special attention to uses of AI systems that could have particularly drastic outcomes. I agree!

"techUK has summarised four top priorities for a successful AI governance regime in the UK" 
https://t.co/aS57txBkSr https://t.co/b3kCcr8QIb
Katherine Holden urges that regulators are given sufficient support and bandwidth so they can properly assess the hard cases that require analysis

@LondonFuturists Dawn Butler MP raises examples of people who were imprisoned after being wrongly identified by AI facial recognition systems as matching the description of someone carrying out a crime https://t.co/IoqFOgDvMx
For a closer look at the pros and cons of the forthcoming EU AI Act, sign up for the @LondonFuturists event featuring Prof Patrick Glauner this Saturday https://t.co/0uoY9RqjCS

Rebecca Long Bailey MP asks if there are countries around the world whose AI regulatory scheme should *not* be followed by the UK. Katherine Holden expresses worries about the "blanket" EU AI Act: it is too inflexible, isn't future proof, and fails to pay attention to outcomes
Katherine Holden recommends UP MPs to look into the Singapore "AI verify" framework for its potential to "build trust through transparency" https://t.co/OwnEKgG1st

Katherine Holden agrees that AI-powered facial recognition can play an important role in flagging up potential mental health issues. Again, any such suggested diagnoses would be a starting point for follow-up investigations by human health professionals

@MillenniumProj @JeromeCGlenn Greg Hands MP points out positive use cases of AI-powered facial recognition system: for example finding a lost child in the middle of a large crowd. Surely a blanket ban on such systems is too drastic?
Another episode from that series which introduces a different set of insights, this time involving @MillenniumProj Executive Director @JeromeCGlenn, is here: https://t.co/HvFU91joJc
For one podcast episode that digs deeper into these topics, listen to this conversation between @cccalum and myself https://t.co/MS5lfGIphK

For my own answers for the successful regulation (and, yes, incentivisation) of fast-changing hard-to-predict AI, see my latest book "The Singularity Principles: Anticipating and Managing Cataclysmically Disruptive Technologies" https://t.co/Yrj1SkkuWD

The expert witnesses are now giving their advice for the general framework for successful regulation of AI. Katherine Holden requests greater clarity and coherence between different regulatory systems that all impact AI in various ways. In my view, a "whole systems view" is vital

Dawn Butler MP asks whether good AI systems could identify and "out-programme" inherent biases introduced by flawed conceptual schemes that are over-trusted by humans (e.g. the reliance on a simple BMI statistic). Manish Patel agrees AI could be *part* of this kind of correction

Innovation in AI health solutions takes place in two related places, says Manish Patel: academia, and small agile startups. The wrong kinds of regulations could damage the vitality of this ecosystem; better regulations could speed things up

Is it true that, as is often said, that the UK is world-leading in life sciences, asks Katherine Fletcher MP. Answering, Manish Patel gives the example of Genomics England and the 100,000 Genomes Project

Expert witness Katherine Holden highlights the potential for AI to more quickly triage potential instances of financial fraud (thereby reducing financial losses). Also to improve how goods from supermarkets are delivered more rapidly to consumers in need of them

A patient harmed by a mistake made by an AI will get lots more adverse tabloid news coverage than a patient harmed by a mistake made by a human doctor. That's why the quality of AI needs to be at a higher level, to avoid the whole field being set back, says Manish Patel

GPs are under "an incredible amount of strain", says Manish Patel, but AI systems could assist with streamlining some of the tedious admin/transfer tasks that GPs face. This is an example of AIs augmenting the capabilities of human employees, improving their work environment

Expert witness Manish Patel refers to occasions when AI clinical diagnostic tools were being misled by background features of the data, and weren't actually picking up truly salient aspects. That's why human verification is needed too

A side comment: MPs are much more impressive when they collaborate constructively across party lines in committees such as this, compared to the name-calling tribalism that is often visible in set pieces in the main chamber of the House of Commons

Katherine Fletcher MP asks about the abilities of AIs to understand and manage situations involving prisoners' dilemmas. One answer would be the success of the Cicero AI in playing the game of strategy and collaboration, Diplomacy https://t.co/D2TkkphEa6

The experts both evade giving hard answers to the question of what they predict for AI in 5 or 10 years, emphasising the unpredictability of future development. But Michael Cohen rightly points out that technological development often comes in bursts

The country which masters a new AI capability first may gain a decisive advantage in the world, points out Michael Osborne. That's why it's not sufficient to rely on countries voluntarily giving up their efforts to be first to develop these new capabilities

Aaron Bell MP asks about the challenges of binding international regulations for AI systems. The experts agree that there are serious dangers with "the current massive arms race" in which countries are moving as quickly as possible to develop the most performative AI

Michael Cohen gets this bit right: in recent years, AI systems have "become much more generalist" - and that's why people are paying more attention to the possible future development of these systems. Here's my account of "broad AI" https://t.co/mHCwNSV6F1

Michael Osborne suggests that police should make *no* use of AI-powered facial recognition. Greg Clark MP is understandably surprised. Surely potential identifications highlighted by AI systems can be useful input to further investigation by police?

Stephen Metcalfe asks "why can't we just pull the plug?" - and then suggests "we shouldn't go down that rabbit hole" regarding AI that spreads over the Internet. However, we ALREADY have widespread algorithms that are very hard to "pull the plug": the Internet itself, Blockchain
Tracey Couch MP is asking the best questions so far - What are the particular risks of black box AI systems? Can AI black box systems be regulated? Can AI assist in the regulation of AI?

Hmm, the "experts" go further off the rails. Michael Cohen suggests it will be relatively straightforward to design AI that won't acquire dangerous emergent new abilities. Only certain types of AI cause major risks, he suggests
Here's the breakthrough paper on the subject of "transformative artificial intelligence" https://t.co/GMXKoV4PO4

Tracey Couch MP asks: is it true we cannot predict when transformative AI arrives? Neither of the experts can reference the definition given by Holden Karnofsky, "precipitates a transition comparable to (or more significant than) the agricultural or industrial revolution"

Committee chair Greg Clark MP gets it right: future AI has the potential to move beyond "helping people" to "supplanting people" in the workforce - for example, in analysing medical data, handling medical administration tasks

Stephen Metcalfe MP asks for evidence of encroachment on human jobs from AI (as opposed to AI augmenting the ability of humans in the workforce). The most compelling answer is in the book "A World Without Work" by Daniel Susskind https://t.co/AMn43lANcg

@maosbot Is all data biased, asks Dawn Butler MP. The expert witnesses fail to emphasise that different notions of fairness and bias are often mathematically incompatible. Approaches that reduce one type of bias often introduce bias along a different dimension https://t.co/WqdP9BpEQa

Many thanks to @DanFaggella, Rohit Talwar (@FastFuture), and @BronwynWilliams for lots of challenging provocations, practical suggestions, and visions of better ways forward! Thanks also to a lively audience, who filled up the chat with insights and queries
D) Attempts to steer the evolution of AGI result in ham-fisted regulations that quash genuine innovation and drive it underground or overseas (where it may take place more carelessly and dangerously)

C) The public react badly to becoming aware of some of these forthcoming possibilities (and the outlandish ideas that "tech elites" are seemingly happy to discuss), resulting in panic, social chaos, demagoguery, and a collapse in civilisation
D) (cont...)

But all these transitional paths are fraught with landmines:
A) AGIs, whilst enormously clever, miscalculate, and annihilate everything (including themselves)
B) AGIs, whilst enormously clever, lack any true sentience or consciousness, so the cosmos becomes soulless
C) (cont...)

These end outcomes include:
1) Humans are essentially unchanged
2) Humans are significantly uplifted
3) A baton is passed to beings significantly more sentient & conscious than us
4) Humans are relocated to secure new locations in paradise-like virtual worlds
5) Human-AGI merger

Humanity's choices for which scenarios to prefer for this transition will depend, in turn, on how we assess and value the various potential end outcomes that could lie beyond the emergence of AGI (Artificial General Intelligence). These end outcomes deserve wider study

Another key takeaway is that the need is stronger than ever to evaluate ASAP, before it's too late, various actions that could be taken NOW to positively influence any forthcoming transition from today's AI to more powerful AI that proceeds beyond human understanding and control

Rather than sugar coating forecasts, futurists should find ways to help the public to clearly understand the radical scenarios that could lie in the relatively near future for humanity. That was one of the conclusions at yesterday's @LondonFuturists event https://t.co/wcikDZDgrP

@j2bryson @cccalum @jacyanthis Yes, you've given a definition of consciousness that is measurable. But that doesn't mean your definition captures what most people have in mind when they refer to consciousness. That's why I'm unconvinced by your proposition that some AIs are already conscious

@j2bryson @cccalum @jacyanthis I DON'T want humanity to build AIs to which we end up owing moral obligations. Even more, I don't want humanity to build AIs that will be part of systems that lead to the devastation of human wellbeing. @eugediana But there are major risks, of course, from AIs that aren't (yet) "completely generally intelligent". Avoiding thinking about these risks because "perfect AGI can't exist", or "perfect AGI won't make mistakes", is *deeply* misguided. "Immature AGI" is what we should fear the most

@j2bryson @cccalum The counterargument, which @JacyAnthis raised, is that AIs may become conscious without our specifically planning for that. It's like how AIs may develop the same convergent secondary goals even if they have different fundamental goals. Consciousness may emerge in a similar way

@j2bryson @cccalum I don't agree that I (and it's the same with many others) *want* to be able to "construct something you owe moral obligation to". In the podcast episode, I proposed we should, for the time being, plan our designs for AI to *avoid* the chance of them becoming sentient/conscious

@j2bryson @cccalum I'm also unsure what features an AI might demonstrate, that would make it a "moral patient" deserving of not being switched off or otherwise deprived of resources, apart from convincing us that it might be conscious (and/or sentient)

@ElUltimoSapiens @michiokaku @RafaMonterdeF @FHIOxford @singularityhub @ProfAndrewScott @BDJFuturist @changeist @WorldFutureSoc @ThomasFrey @FuturistGraeme @MaxMore5 @zoltan_istvan @transhumanismAU @Singularity_NET @futurism @cordeiro @davidasinclair Dear José, which of the "postulates" of transhumanism do you not share?

See https://t.co/IOrt83pFdv for a refresher on how transhumanism views the world, and what transhumanism recommends can and should be done to improve matters

@ElUltimoSapiens @michiokaku @RafaMonterdeF @FHIOxford @singularityhub @ProfAndrewScott @BDJFuturist @changeist @WorldFutureSoc @ThomasFrey @FuturistGraeme @MaxMore5 @zoltan_istvan @transhumanismAU @Singularity_NET @futurism @cordeiro @davidasinclair Transhumanism is open to the idea that some human traits are influenced by genes and could, with care, be improved by biological interventions.
Transhumanism is opposed to (1) dogmatism, (2) totalitarianism, (3) suppression of individual rights.

@ElUltimoSapiens @michiokaku @RafaMonterdeF @FHIOxford @singularityhub @ProfAndrewScott @BDJFuturist @changeist @WorldFutureSoc @ThomasFrey @FuturistGraeme @MaxMore5 @zoltan_istvan @transhumanismAU @Singularity_NET @futurism @cordeiro @davidasinclair What *is* madness, however, is the suggestion in your meme that anyone considering the betterment of the human race is a "biological determinist".

On the contrary, we can (and must) recognise the influence of biology, without downplaying the importance of non-biological factors.

Finally, I apologise for introducing the unlovely abbreviation CCbCA, and look forward to more memorable branding - both for the acronym, and for the name of the concept itself (Carbon Currency based on Carbon Allowances) (5/6)

Both UBI and CCbCA gain some of their attraction from their universality, and from the basic simplicity of the core proposal. But again in both cases, the devil will be in the details - and in the other mechanisms that must be introduced in parallel (4/6)

I'm not saying that CCbCA is the single solution to controlling greenhouse gas emissions - no more than UBI is the single solution to technological underemployment. But in both cases, the proposal could be a significant *part* of a solution (3/6)

Here's the thought behind that comparison. First reactions to the idea - whether UBI or CCbCA - are likely that is too impractical, too idealistic, and too politically infeasible. But upon reflection, the strength of the underlying concept becomes clearer (2/6)

@PeterWardJourno Lots of the background material you provided, Peter, went far beyond the typical narratives about these personalities, without ever straying too far or losing relevance. It was a pleasure to read

But overall, I am happy to recommend "The Price of Immortality" to anyone seeking a broader understanding of the past, present, and possible future(s) of the radical life-extension movement. (That's something which should interest all of us!) (9/9) https://t.co/VsXK3Z4Dse

The weakest part of Ward's book was probably the ending, where a desire to virtue signal seemed to take over. He looked at various possible problems arising as "consequences of immortality" but appeared to be constrained by small-mindedness in these discussions (8/9)

However, the supposed contrast which Ward plays up, with "immortalists" apparently saying one thing and "scientists" apparently saying another, is overdone. In reality, things are more complicated. That trope became increasingly annoying as the book proceeded. (7/9)

Ward's analysis of cryonics (often informed by the views of Mike Darwin) - its vision, its troubled history, its progress, and the issues it faces - has a lot to commend it. The later chapters featuring alternatives to cryonics make good reading too (6/9)

In most cases (but not all), I think Ward's judgements are fair, regarding the trustworthiness/reliability of the people and movements he describes. He is right in some occasions to be pretty angry about mis-sold "solutions" (5/9)

Of the two, I somewhat prefer Ward's book. In part because it is considerably more up-to-date, with its coverage of recent developments. And in part because I find myself in greater sympathy to the underlying philosophy of Ward (a journalist) than Farman (an anthropologist) (4/9)

Both books contain engaging and insightful observations about the people and movements they cover. In both cases, much of what was said was already familiar to me, but also in both cases, there were additional facts which made me wiser (3/9)

There's some overlap with "On Not Dying" by Abou Farman, another book which I recently read, which also explores the motivations and connections of various groups that might be described as "immortalist" (though many dislike that term) (2/9) https://t.co/WSbCnEIj0y

I learned a lot from listening to "The Price of Immortality" by @PeterWardJourno. That book covers a wide range of individuals and communities who are involved, in various ways, in quests to extend lifespan, and, perhaps, achieve indefinite lifespans (1/9) https://t.co/VsXK3Z4Dse

The start of the main narrative in #EmailFromTheFuture is a bit slow. There's no dramatic hook to capture reader/listener interests. But if you're patient, I believe you'll soon find yourself warmly enjoying "Email From the Future" (8/8) https://t.co/FfLy5fWcVy

Don't expect dramatic action sequences or surprise twists in the narrative. It's not that kind of book. But be prepared to have your ideas about future possibilities gently challenged as the book unfolds. You might also find yourself being inspired and heartened (7/8)

I think the narrative loses its credibility in only two places - one concerning how fully AI might develop, and another point which (again) I won't describe here since it turns out to be integral to a major plot line (6/8)

There's an impressive number of different topics woven into the narrative of #EmailFromTheFuture. I won't list them here, since I wouldn't want to spoil readers'/listeners' enjoyment. On the whole, I share the author's judgement about the desirability of various outcomes (5/8)

#EmailFromTheFuture foresees a future that is much better than the present time, in all kinds of fascinating ways. But that future was reached only after citizens of the world united in action against terrible crises in intermediate decades (3/8)

The book mainly takes the form of notes written by a grandfather to his 5 year old grandson. I can relate to that! My grandson is approaching 2 years old, and I can now communicate some non-trivial ideas to him (e.g. about how Lego bricks can fit together to form stairs) (2/8)

I enjoyed listening to the audio version of "Email From the Future: Notes from 2084" by Michael Rogers (@rogersma). It's an example of the kind of fiction the world sorely needs: an optimistic, credible vision of how the next few decades could unfold (1/8) https://t.co/FfLy5fWcVy

But I am glad I read the book. For one thing, it has helped me to appreciate that some transhumanists are far too glib in saying that everything is information and algorithms. I'll add that point into my own description of the transhumanist shadow (10/10) https://t.co/mSNZXoDRz2

Farman might justify his opinions via the sometimes gob-smackingly naive statements he quoted from some of his interviewees. But my view is that he was unfairly selective. He shoehorned his own preconceptions on top of what a richer survey of evidence would show (9/10)
monoculture transhumanists (vs. those who actively encourage diversity); and people focused on information and algorithms (vs. those with broader interests in consciousness and enlightenment) (8/10)

Moreover, I think he failed in his anthropological analysis, by focusing too much on selected parts of the broader immortalist community: technolibertarian (vs. technoprogressive); human-centric (vs. views of transhumanists such as David Pearce about nature as a whole; (7/10)

Worse, Farman often superimposed on his narratives what struck me as a ludicrous over-simplification, tying too many things to notions of whiteness and American culture. (You think people deserve a second chance in life? Hey, you're a white American.) (6/10)

In between all these sections there were tangents that I found more tedious, in which Farman suggested links between his own concepts and long lists of other academics whose ideas often seemed (from the description provided) to be banal (5/10)

Abou Farman also suggested links between these "immortalist" movements and other social and philosophical trends. Many of these links were already familiar to me; others were less so, but tended to make sense. He raised lots of big questions as the discussion proceeded  (4/10)

To the extent that I already knew about these people and activities, the descriptions mainly seemed fair, and often filled in details that I did not know before. I enjoyed these sections, and felt wiser as a result (3/10)

He gives an outsider's point of view of different meetings, conferences & projects over the years - describing the people that he met, their hopes, fears, interactions, organisations & reinventions. He also provides history that goes back decades, sometimes even centuries (2/10)

"On Not Dying: Secular Immortality in the Age of Technoscience" by anthropologist Abou Farman gave me quite a lot to think about. It covers people who variously call themselves cryonicists, immortalists, transhumanists, life extensionists, and more (1/10) https://t.co/GJfkfzR3Hq

Overall, then, I thoroughly recommend "The Man from the Future: The Visionary Life of John von Neumann" by Ananyo Bhattacharya, with the proviso that readers will need to be able to handle fairly technical discussions of various areas of maths and science https://t.co/9XXbuEwg5J

For another "descendant" of von Neumann's ideas on game theory, as explored further at RAND, consider the recent DeepMind publication on "Human-centred mechanism design with Democratic AI", perhaps the most important research on AI alignment yet published https://t.co/Z92yzLK9Nd;

Some of the author's digressions in later chapters, e.g. into the careers of John Nash and (one of my former maths profs) John Horton Conway, at first seemed too tangential, but as the narrative continued, they were tied back splendidly to seeds planted by von Neumann's ideas;

(3) von Neumann's early death, aged just 53, in 1957, came while he was still at the peak of his productive powers, and cruelly robbed humanity of decades of extra insight from von Neumann on key questions for life, computing, technology, and future possibilities;

Returning to this thread, now that I've reached the end of this marvellous book. Conclusion: (1) "The Man from the Future" highlighted many important connections that I previously failed to appreciate; (2) von Neumann's influence across multiple fields of life has been enormous;

Some points this podcast covered: What's required in society to boost truly useful innovation? Different kinds of libertarianism. The People's Republic of Walmart. Moral Machines. Why are there so many irrational narratives these days? The Longevity Dividend. Open clinical trials

Moreover, the simulation hypothesis is meaningful, and credible, even though it (in some versions) may not be a scientific hypothesis. People who react with scorn against the simulation hypothesis are letting their emotions get the better of them

Some things I believe more strongly after finishing the book: Humans will likely be spending lots more time in the future inside huge immersive virtual realities. And that will be a good life, rather than something to be deplored

More plus points for the book: Chalmers weaves in examples from popular culture - films, books, and even pop songs. And he provides accessible explanations of the views of numerous diverse past thinkers. So the book is a good starting point from which to explore further

In a few places, the content became tedious for a while, as Chalmers was being (in my view) over-generous to points that some critics could make against his views. I had less patience for these critics. But the pace soon picked up again, with another set of fascinating ideas

Three weeks later, I've reached the end of "Reality+" by David Chalmers. It's full of mind-stretching material. I *think* I agree with all of his conclusions, across many fields of philosophy: metaphysics, epistemology, values, mind, reality, and the simulation hypothesis

I've seen this too. The dangerous trend is a marginalisation of discussion of AI safety into topics that are perceived to be easier - mainly into research into problems of present-day AI and present-day technology. Talk of future cataclysmically disruptive technologies is shunned

The article isn't just a review of some of the many reasons why creating a safe ("aligned") AGI will be very hard. It also expresses exasperation about lack of effective responses from many of the organisations that you would think should be paying more attention to these risks

I've been reflecting on this cry from the heart from @ESYudkowsky about the lack of progress being made toward a safe route to AGI. It's not an easy read - the argument is very dense in places. The intended audience isn't the general public. But the messages in it need attention

But imagine, in the not-too-distant future, a similar group of audacious geniuses, visionaries, activists, and more, excitedly dabbling with heretical ideas for how artificial intelligence could be improved and deployed. Imagine a bug in their equivalent of smart contracts. Oops.

In reality, the DAO smart contracts had lots of ways for humans to interfere with them, once it was clear that their operation with misaligned with the actual intent of their designers. After all, smart contracts lack any "superintelligence" features. Thank goodness

What's special about crypto smart contracts is that they are *unstoppable* by design. Moreover, "code is law", and isn't meant to be subject to tedious self-serving small-minded human interference. So intervening to lessen the impact of the DAO hack was deeply controversial

More important, arguably, than this detective work, is to raise awareness of how many bright, talented software engineers had reviewed the design and implementation of these DAO smart contracts beforehand, and had failed to spot the fatal flaw

One line of enquiry from the DAO theft is that the author names the person she believes performed the hack, and provides considerable supporting evidence. The name is not in the book itself, but was shared in articles published in parallel with the book https://t.co/H6Ki9lNOOT

"The Cryptopians" also includes an extended account of the theft in 2016 of 3.6 million ETH (worth many billions of USD at present prices) from "the DAO" - the first "distributed autonomous organisation", which had been created with a major defect in its smart contract system

The people covered in "The Cryptopians" will in many cases dislike aspects of what's written about them. This is a "warts and all" account, in which even the heroes and heroines have ugly aspects exposed. The author seems to have conducted very thorough research

At times, this history of the cryptopians reminded me of somewhat similar tumult within the executive teams of Symbian (and the Symbian Foundation). A few episodes that I had almost forgotten about jolted back into my consciousness (see https://t.co/eXlGevMRLY)

I already had some awareness of the people, projects, and escapades involved. (One of the protagonists had spoken at London Futurists back in 2014: https://t.co/2qeFBBdkDa). The book paints a *much* rounder picture, filling in lots of gaps in my understanding

The rest of the subtitle is "The Making of the First Big Cryptocurrency Craze". It's all about Ethereum and the related community of geniuses, visionaries, activists, and more. It starts before the beginning, and runs through to 2018, with an epilogue bringing matters up to date

I've just finished listening to the audio version of the book. The narration is by the author herself, and is full of verve and passion. Emotions that flooded through my headphones included sympathy, admiration, wonder, astonishment, incredulity, outrage, and indignation

Idealism, Greed, Lies. Could be added: Naivety, Hubris, Audacity, Back-stabbing. Huge over-accomplishment and huge under-accomplishment. These are words from the subtitle of "The Cryptopians" by @LauraShin, which tells an epic tale https://t.co/nzuHNxmCKE

I don't agree with every point in his book, but I see his analysis as very timely. If we don't learn from the mistakes made in the past, our aspirations to reach a world of sustainable abundance in the near future might be derailed by a repetition of some of the previous problems

J Storrs Hall has a lot to say about "failures of nerve" and "failures of imagination". About the crippling impact of regulations that are out-dated, clumsy, and ill-informed. And about the dangers of group-think and minds being closed to disturbing new ideas

However, the book raises many questions. "Where is my flying car?" could equally well be entitled "Where is my nanotech?", "Where is abundant nuclear energy?", and "Where is my spacecraft?". It laments society's failures to take wise advantage of technological possibilities

The particular vision in "Where is my flying car" is that of a "Second Atomic Age", featuring applications of atomically precise engineering and nuclear energy (both fission and fusion), with wide implications for travel, agriculture, climate, healthcare, city design, & much more

In all three cases, the books painted apparently plausible pictures of possible applications of technologies that could come to maturity in the decades ahead - applications far beyond mere increments to ordinary human lifestyles

In this way, "Where is my flying car" gave me a reminder of the intellectual thrill I experienced long ago, on first encountering the dazzling ideas in "Engines of Creation" by Eric Drexler and "The Age of Spiritual Machines" by Ray Kurzweil

Ahead of this Saturday's @LondonFuturists event with J. Storrs Hall, I've just finished reading his book "Where is my flying car". Some of the later parts seemed to send tingles up my spine, due to the compelling brilliance of the vision it contained https://t.co/719taeL5Mj

But it's better to act with an objective view of what aging and death implies, rather than to remain under a comforting metaphysical illusion, argues the author. That objective view can spur us, individually and collectively, to take actions in support of radical longevity (5/5)

For readers who have already made a kind of peace with the prospect of aging and death, the book may be deeply unsettling. After all, few of us like to contemplate the prospect of the utter termination of all future growth, experiences, learning, and relationships (4/5)

Each argument is presented sympathetically at first, using quotes from many thinkers that have reputations for being wise and profound, before the damaging implications of these arguments are laid bare, and alternative pro-life positions advanced (3/5)

Arguments reviewed in the book and found wanting include: death is harmless, life is overrated, death is natural, living longer would be boring, life needs a deadline, evolution needs death, overpopulation, social stagnation, immortal dictators, unequal access to treatments (2/5)

What kind of regulatory systems and governance will be best, to avoid any such unintended catastrophes? That's a hard, hard, question. But we mustn't turn away our attention because it's uncomfortable or inconvenient. (6/6)

The most disturbing possibility is that the outbreak arose from actions of people who had very positive intentions - namely, researching mechanisms to reduce the chances of future pandemics causing worldwide problems (4/6)

But it also highlights many examples of actions that were much less admirable: people in both media and academia, as well as in the medical establishment, who sought to turn attention away from facts that were uncomfortable or inconvenient (3/6)

The book highlights many heroic, admirable actions, of Internet sleuths and self-taught researchers around the world, who uncovered evidence which cast new light on the background to the outbreak of the pandemic (2/6)

"Viral: The Search for the Origin of COVID-19" by Alina Chan and Matt Ridley was a book that changed my mind. It marshals lots of evidence that significantly raises the probability that the global pandemic resulted from a laboratory incident (1/6) https://t.co/ouh2WvytJZ

@PSBROOKES Finally, I object to the false opposition that Partridge implies: "People are suffering from disability and loss of quality of life because of ageing. That’s what we should be trying to fix". But solving aging requires the first goal (life quality) too. There's no opposition

Many will be tempted to turn away from the inconvenient facts assembled in "Putin's People", or seek to throw mud on it. But navigating our way out of the looming international crisis requires a clear awareness of these unpleasant realities. So I strongly recommend the book

Although there's much in the book to cause alarm, there are also indications of the weakness and fragility of the Putin regime: problems caused by the regime's mode of operation. That fragility offers some hope for a better future, but it also threatens a downturn into more chaos

At times, I was reminded of the violent drama of "Peaky Blinders", the television drama series about larger-than-life gangsters in the UK between WW1 and WW2. But Putin's people make the fictional Shelby family and their associates look like Sunday School teachers

The book is over 600 pages long and has a huge cast of characters. The analysis is relentless. At times, I became wearied while listening - but then my attention was jolted back on realising a horrible new connection to one or other piece of recent history

One of the most frightening books I have ever read: "Putin's People: How the KGB Took Back Russia and Then Took On the West" by @CatherineBelton.

@OwenJones84 Stuart Russell was asked about AI and social justice in the Q&A portion after his 3rd Reith lecture. He mentioned how individual tuition can make a big difference to someone's opportunities in life, and that AI tutors could provide better education to all https://t.co/wIukryD3B1

@I_am_ludd @OwenJones84 (I acknowledge that society as a whole will become more complicated due to multiple AIs intervening and interacting in novel ways. So the models used for predictions will need to become more elaborate. But that's no reason to think the task will be impossible)

@I_am_ludd @OwenJones84 Humans already make predictions of possible outcomes from interventions they are contemplating. What I have in mind is simply that AI will be able to help humans to foresee the range of possible outcomes more reliably.

@I_am_ludd @OwenJones84 There will be many practical issues in developing and managing AI with common sense. But I am not impressed by any arguments using Godel's theorem to supposedly rule out the possibility of such an AI
See also "Critics of 'Don’t Look Up' Are Missing the Entire Point" https://t.co/ANlJq5P0cl

@I_am_ludd @OwenJones84 For more on notions of potential superdemocracy and sustainable superabundance - and on the grave perils posed by poorly managed NBIC (nanotech, biotech, infotech, and cognotech) - see my latest book "Vital Foresight: The Case for Active Transhumanism" https://t.co/MJ5VDY4BNy

@I_am_ludd @OwenJones84 AI could also have a critical role in calculating in real-time the overall consequences of economic and political actions - provided we can agree what are the appropriate "externalities" to be included in such a calculation

@I_am_ludd @OwenJones84 AI could have particular value in aiding the deliberation of citizens' assemblies - helping the participants to transcend partisan views, and suggesting creative new syntheses of different suggestions

@I_am_ludd @OwenJones84 Like today's AI can help find interesting material scattered over the Internet, tomorrow's AI should be able to identify straightaway whether politicians are speaking honestly or dishonestly, and whether their arguments stack up. Judgement will be swift and incontrovertible

@I_am_ludd @OwenJones84 Like today's AI (artificial intelligence) can anticipate how proteins will fold in three dimensions, tomorrow's AI, with common sense alongside its existing powerful computational abilities, should help us to anticipate how society is likely to respond to various interventions

@I_am_ludd @OwenJones84 Before we can fully benefit from technologies of abundance, we'll need to take advantage of technologies that advance transparency, openness, creative problem solving, agility, collective understanding, and human transformation - the technologies of what I call "superdemocracy"

@I_am_ludd @OwenJones84 The most transformative technologies will be the ones that enable fully automated luxury for all - technologies of sustainable abundance. With more than enough for everyone, lots of previous battles over scarcity should fade away. But bad politics stands in the way of that future

@I_am_ludd @OwenJones84 "help" is the correct word here. No technology, no matter how clever, can guarantee that it will, by itself, advance social justice. That technology could instead be misused. But there definitely are technologies that will place important new opportunities in our collective grasp

In conclusion, "Rationality" isn't just a spirited defence of the importance of rationality ("the fourth 'R'", as Pinker calls it at one point). It's also a spirited defence of the value of philosophy. My judgement is that both arguments succeed.

There's lots more in "Rationality" that should repay reading. In contrast to some of Pinker's earlier books, I remember nothing with which I disagreed. Instead, I found perspectives that pulled together in illuminating new ways material that I was already familiar with

Hence the need for public coordination of methods to prioritise rationality over irrationality: peer reviews, randomised scientific tests, independent fact-checkers, education in probability and critical thinking, and punishments for deliberate or careless spreading of falsehoods

Second, however, as for the original "Tragedy of the commons", what is individually rational for each person can add up to a very bad outcome for everyone. Thus with irrationality: spreading false information erodes general understanding and leads society into very bad decisions

One "aha" for me was Pinker's notion of "The tragedy of the rationality commons". First, it can often be rational for someone to be irrational. (This can protect the inner stories and myths that give us a sense of meaning. And it can give us good status within our adopted tribe)

Given the waves of outlandish irrationality that are evident all around us, it's particularly important to understand the causes of this irrationality - and the likely consequences in case these waves continue. Pinker had good answers here.

I found much to value in the new book by Steven Pinker, "Rationality: What It Is, Why It Seems Scarce, Why It Matters". The writing throughout is lean, engaging, elegant, and convincing. I found myself laughing out loud at times (in a good way) https://t.co/v6ZqxXRC91

In conclusion, the idea of Andrew Yang leading a third party in the USA to break through the deep logjam and dysfunction of present US politics, and possibly even to become President, isn't quite as unlikely as I had previously though. I wish him well!

Next, a note about the narration of the audio version of "Forward: Notes on the Future of our Democracy". It was read by Andrew himself, and it helped his humanity to shine through. He might be dismissed in some quarters as a technology geek, but there's truly a lot more to him!

@JOEBOTxyz Good, we've found a point of agreement. The question is how to enhance humanity, not to lose our humanity. Technology (along with education, politics, etc) can help us to reach higher levels of health, creativity, vitality, and consciousness. But only if approached wisely

@JOEBOTxyz Which kinds of "cyborgs" do you disagree with? Humans that wear clothes? Humans that use watches and spectacles? Humans with embedded pacemakers? Humans who consult Google or Wikipedia to augment their intelligence? Humans whose resistance to disease is augmented by antibiotics?

@JOEBOTxyz Two hundred years ago, the typical human lifespan was around 30 years. Huge numbers of children died before the age of five. Poverty was widespread. Education was just for the very few. Thanks to science, technology, education, and politics, humanity was able to move forward

@JOEBOTxyz Transhumanists have no hatred of being human. Instead there's a clear understanding that we can improve on some of our inherited characteristics. The human condition can, and should, be improved by education, by great literature, by art, by philosophy, and, yes, by science & tech

@didou @Alci_Malapi @ProfSteveFuller @zoltan_istvan It was Jim Collins' fine book "Good to Great" that raised my appreciation, many years ago, of the importance of blending realism with optimism. It's an insight that has stood the test of time in my experience https://t.co/agc4XkGvjr

@didou @Alci_Malapi @ProfSteveFuller @zoltan_istvan In my 25 years immersed in the high technology industry, watching successes and failures, I saw plenty of faith that proved to be ill-founded, and plenty of wishful optimism that crashed on the rocks of reality. The approach I prefer is "realistic optimism"

@didou @Alci_Malapi @ProfSteveFuller @zoltan_istvan My general point, by the way, is that transhumanism cannot succeed by operating separately from other important political and social currents. Active Transhumanism involves working closely with the best of existing initiatives from across the human spectrum

@didou @Alci_Malapi @ProfSteveFuller @zoltan_istvan Where transhumanism can help here, in due course, is by helping spread tools and therapies that calm down our inner demons and defuse the mental poisons. For early suggestions for what should become possible see (2/2) https://t.co/cfVg6FP1mk

@didou @Alci_Malapi @ProfSteveFuller @zoltan_istvan Despite the deep-rooted poisons that infest many parts of today's body politics, I still see a powerful healing role for well-grounded efforts to bridge differences in party affiliation and ideological outlook, such as proposed by Jonathan Haidt (1/2) https://t.co/wwrjl5ImrM

@didou @Alci_Malapi @ProfSteveFuller I'm with you there. As I say in the video introducing "Transcending Politics", "There's no escape. The journey to a healthier society inevitably involves politics" https://t.co/yVQaT6ZC5G

@didou @Alci_Malapi @ProfSteveFuller But it's by no means going to be straightforward. That's why I pick concerns about "Divided Aging" as one of the 11 landmines that have the potential to detonate, blocking humanity's journey to what should be a sustainable superabundance (5/5) https://t.co/EqfsMFR668

@didou @Alci_Malapi @ProfSteveFuller My forecast is that the appeal of healthier aging, and the associated economic and humanitarian benefits, will cut across existing political, religious, and ideological divides. People from all sides will find ways to justify enabling access to these therapies (4/n)
@didou @Alci_Malapi @ProfSteveFuller This argument has a name: the Longevity Dividend. It even reached the pages of Nature recently (3/n) https://t.co/9gmuxmBue8

@didou @Alci_Malapi @ProfSteveFuller This doesn't apply at the moment, since the benefits of existing therapies are still relatively modest (and there may be side-effects). But once the evidence is clearer, public pressure will change. See the argument made in (3/n) https://t.co/qZ1wmGhLKR

@didou @Alci_Malapi @ProfSteveFuller Here's the argument about democratic provision of life extension therapies that Aubrey de Grey has been making for around twenty years. For treatments that can significantly improve healthspan, there will be overwhelming economic pressure to make them available (2/n)

@didou @Alci_Malapi @ProfSteveFuller The increasing politicisation of what should be non-partisan issues is, indeed, worrying. It may be that some once-great countries suffer falls from grace on account of this increased dysfunction. But it's also possible that cooler heads will prevail (1/n)

@didou @Alci_Malapi And to help spread these ideas more widely, I'm now in the process of producing (and curating) a suite of videos covering what I'm calling the Vital Syllabus. @didou @Alci_Malapi I've made a number of attempts over recent years to describe and anticipate the landscape in which that conversation could evolve. E.g. my books "Transcending Politics", "Sustainable Superabundance" and "RAFT 2035" (3/n) https://t.co/4vGEzlEUGO

@didou @Alci_Malapi The dialog between transhumanism and mainstream politics is still at a very early stage. But I expect that conversation to transform pretty rapidly, as public understanding of what's at stake increases (slowly at first, but then more quickly) (2/n)

@didou @Alci_Malapi The existential challenges to the body politic, in the US and elsewhere, come not from transhumanism but from accelerating capabilities of technology, and the resulting disruptions in society. Transhumanism is the answer here, not the question (1/n)

The #CogX2021 panel agrees that scanning can produce false positives regarding potential early cancers. But greater specificity can be attained by (1) using multiple different scanning methods, (2) tracking potential tumours by repeated tests over time https://t.co/vGrjTetLnb
Late stage cancer detection results in a 5 year survival rate of <20%. Early stage detection leads to >80% chance of 5 year survival - @EmiGal at #CogX2021 https://t.co/lyukQZ8UCE

Full body MRI scans to check for cancers used to be very expensive: patients would need to spend lots of time inside the scanner, with trained personnel attending. But improved AI algorithms allow people to be scanned more quickly, reducing costs - @EmiGal at #CogX2021 https://t.co/lkkbE82XMx

There's a lot of press about cancer "wonder drugs", but most cancers are cured by surgery. And that's only possible if cancers are detected early. That's why AI to improve scanning and early detection is so important - James Peach at #CogX2021 https://t.co/o0GQe5BcPg
Next on the #CogX2021 Health & Wellbeing stage: "AI's fight to eliminate cancer" with @SarahKerruish, @EmiGal, and James Peach of @data_can_hub https://t.co/3wwjAn5SGe https://t.co/6fBYFsYsUU

As more and more data is collected from wearables and other means, AI will be able to improve its predictions of future health consequences of our personal actions. More precise biomarkers of aging are likely to emerge as a result - @PetaVard at #CogX2021 https://t.co/65RjzJ5iCo

For a model for future pro-longevity drugs, consider the way statins were approved following measurements of cholesterol. What we need first are better measurements of aging biomarkers and evidence that drugs can reduce these parameters. AI can help here! @JamesPeyer at #CogX2021 https://t.co/MRpCZbzM00

I agree with the assessment that seriously flawed conclusions are being drawn from this research - "We probably cannot slow the rate at which we get older because of biological constraints" - This fails to consider significant future interventions in our biology #CogX2021

"We aren't living longer: Our improved lifespan is the result of not dying young" - here's the Oxford report mentioned by @TinaWoods at #CogX2021 - but the panel dismisses it as "lazy reporting" https://t.co/0IdbZjPeYp
I would add, as further background, my own "The Abolition of Aging" #CogX2021 :-) https://t.co/jJEkTEIaoo https://t.co/mRXUDLKJvf
