My question for the AI Governance panel at #CogX2021: What are examples of *bad* coordination between different national groups each trying to regulate technology? What have the consequences been?

Next at #CogX2021 is something different: "Death is just a technical problem... Progress in longevity science is abundant at the moment" featuring @JamesPeyer, @PetaVard, @RobbieStamp42, and @TinaWoods https://t.co/3wwjAn5SGe https://t.co/22LXZkNFKP

Nations traditionally were large enough to counter the power of large corporate monopolies. But with corporations being even larger these days, transnational coordination (like the EU) is needed to counter their power - @j2bryson at #CogX2021 https://t.co/LdaZP838qk

Starting at the beginning: three reasons the world still needs nations, suggests @j2bryson at #CogX2021 - areas of the world have mutual interest in good neighbourly behaviour; a local monopoly of force; units responsible for the human rights of everyone in a given area https://t.co/rXLZhzTeUC

"AI Governance: the role of the nation in a transnational world" - next on the #CogX2021 Ethics & Society stage, featuring @j2bryson, @sanakb, @GavinFreeguard, and @simcd https://t.co/TyhbPBc2QY https://t.co/mZWRcgCOVh

Nathan Bookbinder-Ryan points out that @CDEIUK have published this morning a set of examples of "light patterns" in their report "Active choices: Interim findings" #CogX2021 https://t.co/fhjFeobZaE https://t.co/vQZEbofx4q

Software that is better at detecting and respecting user interests sounds attractive, but has a risk of increasing existing problems from filter bubbles, points out @PhilBeaudoin at #CogX2021 https://t.co/s9BovL7RZK

Current software is good at recognising when a user wants X (e.g. a chocolate bar) but not when the user wants to not want X - @CDEIUK’s Nathan Bookbinder-Ryan envisions future software that is better able to serve user's underlying desires #CogX2021 https://t.co/GSQtDyfSUp

#CogX2021 @laura_ellis highlights the importance of software being able to explain to users (when asked) why various choices have been made regarding the content displayed. This explainability will increase user trust https://t.co/fGoSiwFTTe

A "dark pattern" is when a feature of the UI is designed to promote the choices desired by the platform provider, rather than ones that might be better for the user. For example, making the unsubscribe link less visible - Nathan Bookbinder-Ryan at #CogX2021 https://t.co/oV5sB85kjH
@rhys_the_davies I had the same assessment of the (non-)answer given by Sir Adrian Smith. But I don't think it was just a lack of time. It seemed like a lack of sympathy.

#CogX2021 Ethics stage at 12: "There’s plenty of evidence of bad practice and filter bubbles that disempower or frustrate users online. Can better design lead users to better decision-making?" - @PhilBeaudoin, @laura_ellis, @CDEIUK’s Nathan Bookbinder-Ryan https://t.co/TyhbPBc2QY https://t.co/5BHDHfEZe6
I like this questions tabled at #CogX2021 by @rhys_the_davies: "Could the UK national AI strategy not be focused on enabling and facilitating *international* AI strategy and collaboration?"
The full text of the EU-US Summit Statement "Towards a renewed Transatlantic partnership" #CogX2021 https://t.co/atlCtK6HCH

Mentioned just now at #CogX2021: agreement “to establish an EU-US Joint Technology Competition Policy Dialogue that would focus on approaches to competition policy and enforcement, and increased co-operation in the tech sector” https://t.co/hmJeQOWGn9

I would add: strategy needs to look at OT as well as SW - that is, at forthcoming Opportunities and Threats, as well as current Strengths and Weaknesses. The AI council recommendations seems to offer little foresight on OT #CogX2021

I agree with @Andy_at_public at #CogX2021 - our strategy for AI needs to be more than a wishlist. A strategy needs an understanding of existing strengths and weaknesses, and decisions on which strengths to build on, and how to make weaknesses irrelevant

The single most important pieces of advice for shaping the national AI strategy? "National positioning within an international context", "A strategy, not a wishlist: it needs to be actionable: what to do, and what to stop doing" #CogX2021
The four panellists are all seated together in the same room. But most of the audience (like me) are remote #CogX2021 https://t.co/YtxQydb3Lt
The 16 recommendations from the AI Council "to help the government develop a UK National AI Strategy" #CogX2021 from https://t.co/eFULbYjCWB https://t.co/uosgVAy5dN

"What the UK needs from a National AI Strategy... a look at the AI Council's 16 recommendations" with Sir Adrian Smith of @TuringInst, @RachelColdicutt, @CarolineFDaniel, and @andy_at_public - next at #CogX2021 https://t.co/jtwzGH9syN https://t.co/EHnAdb3hDm

One unanswered question from this #CogX2021 panel: @MarcWarner10 highlighted five core ways to evaluate AI algorithms: doing what we want them to do, fairness, privacy, robustness, and explainability. Do other AI safety researchers agree these are the right dimensions to monitor?

A significant concrete result from recent extra funding of AI safety? The insight that, with AI, there's both an inner alignment problem and and outer alignment problem - Jaan Tallinn at #CogX2021. "It's a bit technical" - but see https://t.co/8g6Liow918 https://t.co/7oFalZC4fL

Instead of talking about our AI systems as "black boxes", a more accurate description is "dark grey boxes", since it *is* possible to obtain data about what's happening inside these systems (though that's no reason for any complacency) - @MarcWarner10 at #CogX2021 https://t.co/f611SpiKPE

The AI industry must avoid repeating the mistake of the nuclear energy industry, which has fallen far short of its potential on account of not putting enough priority on questions of safety - Jaan Tallinn, #CogX2021 https://t.co/6LzVDCckjB

"AI adoption is delegation to automated decision makers... If you are able to delegate well, you are able to increase your overall competence... but if you delegate badly, you might get something completely different than you originally had in mind" - Jaan Tallinn #CogX2021 https://t.co/JMiMGep1r1

"AI Safety: Today and Tomorrow" with Jaan Tallinn (seed funder of @CSERCambridge), @MarcWarner10, and @Liv_Boeree, starting at 10am on the #CogX2021 Ethics & Society Stage https://t.co/TyhbPBc2QY https://t.co/NoGDwKn6us

We need to beware "imposter innovations" in what is becoming an increasingly crowded space, warns #RobertDowneyJr at #CogX2021 - people who are able to say things that *sound* good regarding green innovation https://t.co/eDP9tWrywN

He's been trying to do green investments for ten years, says @tfadell, but there's much greater momentum now than before. Publicity around e.g. Greta Thunberg is helping to change the public mood #CogX2021 https://t.co/7liiGr9vIc
@mm0jxi @drkatedevlin That thought was on my mind too, John. Tracking is an inevitable part of modern life. We can't abolish it. Intead, we have to find ways to minimise downsides of it.
Issue on the top of his mind, needing innovation: plastics, says @tfadell - we have far too much of it (e.g. in our supermarkets), and it all lasts far too long. #CogX2021 https://t.co/1gca5VIAUY
The final #CogX2021 session of the day: "Why innovation is the only way out of the climate crisis" with @tfadell, @RobertDowneyJr, and @ES_Entrepreneur https://t.co/vh7mghiuDg https://t.co/EytX7Zl0XK

Users will reject smart meters if there's any possibility that they're tracking (or could infer) which films they're watching on Netflix, suggests #GRamchurn at #CogX2021. Without trust, technology won't deliver its potential benefits https://t.co/HXJ5veroRk

We need to beware "the human crumple zone" says @JackStilgoe at #CogX2021 - referring to the notion introduced by @m_c_elish - in which blame for tech failures is assigned too easily to "human error" instead of flawed system design https://t.co/DRySGcZN8C https://t.co/bRYJTxVRLV

We also need to look at Ownership (as well as the three Ps), suggests @GRamchurn at #CogX2021. For me, I would highlight Accountability. Providers of technology shouldn't be able to evade responsibility via one-sided license agreements, etc https://t.co/f8gsvAWqqG

@ProfSteveFuller The usual answer, of course, is that it's not about individual scientists. It's about the overall scientific community. It's not perfect. But it contains various mechanisms to correct for the fallibility of individual participants.

Whether systems can be trusted depends on three Ps, suggests @JackStilgoe at #CogX2021: Performance, Process, and Purpose. (Then he mentions Privacy in his next sentence. A fourth P?) https://t.co/GD0x1AzoDY

So-called "autonomous systems" incorporate lots of human design and are subject to ongoing human support and influence, points out @JackStilgoe at #CogX2021 - let's not be misled by the words that are in wide use https://t.co/zjNmJmEOTr
@ProfSteveFuller I wonder how data could be collected to allow an objective analysis of this question. Surely some philosophers or sociologists of science must have looked at it before?

@BVLSingler It's been my pleasure to add a few questions into the mix, of what has been a fascinating set of discussions. As someone who often moderates sessions myself, I know the value of having a set of questions to choose between

Next up on the Ethics & Society stage at #CogX2021: "The risks of adopting AI at scale, how we can reduce these risks without restricting progress, and the critical role the public plays" with @drKateDevlin, @GRamchurn, and @JackStilgoe https://t.co/hR7K3l3rCW https://t.co/ER4oWO4ZyE
The biggest problem with news sources isn't just that they often distort what they report about. It's the news stories that are omitted altogether - Max Tegmark at #CogX2021 https://t.co/s84XBbz2Kj

Max Tegmark accepts that scientists are often biased and deserve criticism. Examples include scientists who were motivated to deny the links between smoking and cancer. But science as a whole is arguably the least corrupt institution in society - Max Tegmark at #CogX2021 https://t.co/YJID90OaBm

What the data shows is that news sources vary in predictable ways, not just along a left-right axis, but also along a big media / small media axis. It would be far better to receive news in less biased ways - Max Tegmark at #CogX2021 https://t.co/RZ6t6M84Zy
@ProfSteveFuller Agreed - we need to learn from the insights of the sociology of science too. I'll try to ask an appropriate question to Max...
Science avoids giving powerful entities (governments, big companies, religions, etc) a special influence over fact-checking - Max Tegmark at #CogX2021 https://t.co/ZaOQa9zHk1
We need to move away from trying to treat symptoms. We need to develop a more accurate diagnosis of the underlying problem - Max Tegmark at #CogX2021 https://t.co/ZGeq3OHOAS
The threats from AI to democracy aren't just a few decades away. They're strongly in the present too - Max Tegmark at #CogX2021 https://t.co/BVOBEf8ybf
Another title for this talk: "AI for helping rather than hacking democracy" #CogX2021 https://t.co/4lx54DKi14
@RobMcCargow Ah, it's surely easier to participate remotely! I can switch instantly between different #CogX2021 streams. And take breaks whenever it's convenient to me...

Probably one of the highlights of #CogX2021 next: mega-thinker "Mad Max" @Tegmark will be interviewed by @BVLSingler on "How we can use machine learning to detect bias in the media, and how we could wield this power to strengthen our democracy" https://t.co/KzetHQhpEd https://t.co/Scfx1uX22s

The thing that causes Rob Glaser the biggest worry for the next ten years is the potential increase of tribalism and inequality in the world. AI can help us deal with these issues - but only in a secondary way. (That is, political actions are needed too!) #CogX2021 https://t.co/Oy90LeuB5U

Rob Glaser highlights the way in which intuitively compelling notions of fairness actually end up in contradiction with each other (using an example from the Brian Christian book). This shows there's no escape from humans having to review and take hard ethical decisions #CogX2021 https://t.co/JGfmyNq2RK

Rob Glaser at @CogX2021 gives a shout out to the book "The Alignment Problem: Machine Learning and Human Values" by @BrianChristian. I echo that endorsement: it provides a rich perspective on questions of AI fairness and bias https://t.co/zOD4jlH4RY

Recognition technology can be exculpatory as well as suggesting the identification of guilty parties. That is, it can raise the probability that someone is innocent. That applies for DNA evidence and it should apply for facial recognition tech too - Rob Glaser at #CogX2021 https://t.co/ZQb6KBCx9V

There's no need for all countries to adopt the very same regulations about facial recognition technology. However, a transparent discussion is needed in every country - Rob Glaser at #CogX2021 https://t.co/UZ6wxJ5pbz

Rob Glaser gives the example of food labelling: regulations prescribe even the minimum size of font for labels giving certain information about the ingredients. Similar disclosure rules are needed for algorithms of all sorts, to convey information transparently #CogX2021 https://t.co/6xCeQPk6PB

The SAFR technology from RealNetworks that Rob Glaser is describing at #CogX2021: "Offers accurate, fast, unbiased face recognition and additional computer vision features. Optimized to run on virtually any camera or camera-enabled device" https://t.co/o61aa3shke

Next up at #CogX2021: "Ethics and Bias in AI" with @CarolineFDaniel (Brunswick Group) and Rob Glaser (RealNetworks): "How can we prevent the individual from paying the price for a loss of privacy and still ensure safety for the greater community?" https://t.co/vh7mghiuDg https://t.co/OvEObk62xq

This fascinating talk by Stuart Russell is the first one I've attended at #CogX2021 that gives me a strong reason to change a section in my forthcoming new book (to include a mention of probabilistic programming), before it gets published https://t.co/uJcDfEZ24u

Summary slide. The real progress will come from combination approaches. One advantage of probabilistic programming that has already been obtained is a 1000-fold speedup in various compilers #CogX2021 https://t.co/HINpYQtUXE

One goal of probabilistic programming, says Stuart Russell at #CogX2021, is to enable knowledge generated by earlier learning exercises to be fed back into the learning system, along with new data, to generate richer knowledge in subsequent iterations https://t.co/EZJttzAg3B

Stuart Russell starts by sharing the view of Francois Chollet about serious limitations of "current deep learning techniques" in which many "applications are completely out of reach" #CogX2021 https://t.co/MR1vUkdN6l

"The next wave: the game-changing potential of probabilistic programming, what makes it so different from deep learning, and why it could help propel programming culture forward" - Next at #CogX2021, Prof Stuart Russell in discussion with @GemmaMilne https://t.co/KzetHQhpEd https://t.co/YJfr5X3lnq

Regardless of the type of extremist movement, there's usually a common factor leading people to join them, namely a desire for belonging and meaning, to address their personal feelings of vulnerability. That applies across the ideological spectrum - @vidhya_ra at #CogX2021 https://t.co/0ZvdU4K1WF

What might @MoonshotTeam do differently in the future? @vidhya_ra answers that it would be great to have more evidence about which specific kinds of online interventions have the best overall effects #CogX2021 https://t.co/XbbLDTCoUE

Linkages between different extremist or conspiracist networks are stronger nowadays than before. It appears these links are being deliberately cultivated, in order to grow these groups - @vidhya_ra at #CogX2021 https://t.co/EbQcx2ac8t

This is an example of an "empathy anger ad" - an ad which asks people if they're feeling angry, and if they would prefer not to feel in that way. It seems that people in various extremist groups sometimes do click on these ads, with good results - @vidhya_ra at #CogX2021
An example of how social media can respond to various searches by providing links that can help people avoid extremist routes - shared by @vidhya_ra at #CogX2021 https://t.co/PVxWDf1owE

The work of @vidhya_ra at @MoonshotTeam started by interviewing people drawn to white supremacist groups: what led them to join, and what in due course led them to leave. It became clear that similar approaches could be useful for other sorts of extremist groups too #CogX2021 https://t.co/Yl2Vr4sRpj
@camisade I think the answer is: it depends. I'd distrust any simple formula for this kind of situation. But "show empathy" is probably *part* of the answer

"A look at the burgeoning counter-radicalization industry, how we can prevent conspiracy-laced hate, and protect vulnerable individuals" - the next Cyber & Defence session at #CogX2021 is "The dark web", with @vidhya_ra and @ClaudineTinsman https://t.co/V2OsH3dGSK https://t.co/XVEKp1sACS

The discussion reminds me of people who used to scoff at the idea of finding genuine romance on an Internet dating site. Or that consumers would never want to shop somewhere that lacked real human salespeople #CogX2021

Big Tech should be kept out of childcare and eldercare; such care is far better provided by humans, says @STurkle at #CogX2021. But AI systems can make a big difference in child education, and Grace (a robot) from @Singularity_NET is poised to make a big difference in eldercare https://t.co/ZANWNDPXFt

Following up: therapists (human) can provide advice to people who are experiencing problems they themselves can never directly experience. E.g. they might be a male, with a female client. The ability to have the exact same experience isn't needed to offer useful advice #CogX2021 https://t.co/WkEFQip19u

My view, contra what @STurkle is saying at #CogX2021. Psychological advice can be really valuable, even when delivered by a professional counsellor (a human) who only "simulates" genuine concern for clients. It's the same with simulated genuine concern from AIs https://t.co/Y3MUILIwgA

"Empathy doesn't mean you like somebody. It means you are ready to listen to them and understand them, and understand not just the place they are coming from but their problem... Empathy is the fuel for democracy" - @STurkle at #CogX2021 (final remark is from Joe Biden) https://t.co/Qi2I3KI6wl
@informingchoice Many thanks for these kind words Steve. If you don't mind, I'll include them on the "advance praise" pages at the start of the book :-)

That takes us nicely to the "Empathy and ethics in the workplace" session, up next on the Future of Work & HR stage at #CogX with Sherry Turkle (@STurkle) and Tim Leberecht (@TimLeberecht) exploring "the subjective side of people’s relationships with tech" https://t.co/h2wVGQruui https://t.co/KDvZRHg582

To talk to our "crazy uncles" etc who have fallen into conspiracy networks, a vital skill is empathy. Brow-beating people with facts is unlikely to be effective - @MWendling at #CogX2021 https://t.co/prXLhU4Jdy

Conspiracy networks are by no means all the same. Some (e.g. anti-vax) claim to look at evidence in favour of their claims. But others thrive on apparent failures of their predictions! QAnon started with a failed prediction about Hillary Clinton - @AmarAmarasingam at #CogX2021 https://t.co/eutnIWe7IV

People are quick learners. They soon work out ways to evade social media checks on what they are publishing, for example by subtly changing the wording they use - @MWendling at #CogX2021 https://t.co/6U0Db7WBXn

We should have resources in place ready to assist people in conspiracy networks when they are starting to question things, but at any time we shouldn't expect most people in these networks to want to engage with these resources - @AmarAmarasingam at #CogX2021 https://t.co/ZC0Sx8FRTe

Banning a community like QAnon from mainstream social media is a two-edged sword. It pushes people into unmoderated social media, where there is greater extremism. A better solution is improved media literacy, taught to people of all ages - @AoifeGall at #CogX2021 https://t.co/bafZLPY3c5

Most people weren't particularly seeking out QAnon content; it arrived in their social media inbox without them asking for it - @AoifeGall emphasises the consequences of tech algorithms in drawing more people into a conspiracy #CogX2021

In a conference with many highlights, this discussion seems particularly relevant: "Gone are the days when conspiracy theories existed only in the fringes of society. From capitol riots to vaccine boycotting, they’ve become a mainstream threat with real consequences" #CogX2021 https://t.co/l7wtZl8lzo

"Down The Rabbit Hole: QAnon, conspiracists and the new threat" with @ZoeTabary, @AoifeGall, @AmarAmarasingam, and @MWendling. How do these networks grow, and how can we mitigate the damage - next on the Cyber & Defence stage at #CogX2021 https://t.co/V2OsH3dGSK https://t.co/8NmI6xXfdz

The way that public functions are now becoming privatised, under systems provided by big tech corporations, should be compared to the enclosures of the commons a few centuries past - @KateCrawford replies to @Azeem at #CogX2021 https://t.co/vh7mghiuDg https://t.co/X16hUEFzq7

Any analysis of military threats in the 2020s needs to avoid any hard separation between different types of warfare - e.g. nuclear, biological, conventional, disinfo, cyber - since they all coexist and interact - General @TonyT2Thomas at #CogX2021 https://t.co/fwMahtieq5

General @TonyT2Thomas points out past examples, involving both US and Iranian military, in which humans made bad judgments under pressure for quick decisions, leading to civilian loss of life. @schulzb589 That's a different question. That's about which approach is most likely to lead to AGI, that is, how much mileage there could be in non-Hawkins neural networks. Not about how such an AGI could be controlled once it is created

@schulzb589 To be fair to Jeff Hawkins, I'm sure he sees the dangers of projects like Maven (AI in weapons systems). But his view is that that danger is because of misuse of AI by careless, impetuous humans. My view is that future AI will be dangerous even if deployed by careful, calm humans

An update after I've listened to the rest of the book: the final part of "A Thousand Brains" provides a fine introduction to various important themes about the future of humanity, the future of evolution, and the future of intelligence. There's plenty here worth pondering further

And one point where the material was less convincing was his Chapter 9, "When machines are conscious". I much prefer the analysis of this area by Mark Solms, "The Hidden Spring: A Journey to the Source of Consciousness" https://t.co/ARZ5m75rHh
@CDNBiohacker It's definitely worth reading, despite my strong disagreement with (so far) that one topic. The writing style is good, as well as (most of) the content
Anyway, I still have the final six chapters of the book to read, and am looking forward to doing so

In contrast, the material in his earlier chapters strikes me as being world class, and will repay careful study. It even explains how a new wave of major progress in AI capability might take place in the next couple of decades

There's no need for an AGI to be coupled with something akin to the desires of the "old brain" portions of human intelligence, for it to have values that turn out to be misaligned with ongoing human flourishing. Misalignment can arise in many different ways

That was the chapter on "The Existential Risks of Machine Intelligence". Hawkins shows only a superficial understanding of the arguments of Stuart Russell and many others as to the uncontrollability of AIs with capabilities far in excess of ours

The 11th chapter of "A Thousand Brains: A New Theory of Intelligence" by Jeff Hawkins was a real disappointment, after 10 very good chapters on brain science and ideas for how to create AGI https://t.co/jmYLNy1hPn

I see that another reviewer has expressed the same reservation about "Beyond Bad", whilst (like me) recommending that the book be read. For more about the book, and other reviews, see https://t.co/W8MX4exISj https://t.co/Ui9fBduD7v

The author was fair, in my view, in his criticisms of many "moralists" and ethicists. Where I disagreed was with his advocacy of rejecting morality altogether. Morality involves overcoming impulses, and consciously strengthening various habits. We absolutely need that today
After all, we cannot hope to make progress with the vexed question of "ethical AI" when so much of our thinking about "ethical humans" remains on shaky grounds

I appreciated a great deal in "Beyond Bad: How obsolete morals are holding us back" by @CJPaley - the evolutionary origins of our group-based systems of morals, and the urgent need to transcend the drawbacks of these systems https://t.co/hZXPtSK33B

See also the film "The Dissident" for a different angle on some of the same themes from "This Is How They Tell Me The World Ends". It features the use for some very foul purposes of some of the spyware covered in the book https://t.co/hbHRZ2Uigz

So what might destroy (large parts of) the world may be a potent miscombination of human greed and short-sightedness, pervasive IT infrastructure with inherent weaknesses, and (narrow) AI systems that bring their users short-term benefits ahead of long-term ruin

Something not explored, however, is the complicating effect of software that is written (or configured) by machine learning systems, in which the rationale for various decisions is often hard to determine, due to the opaque nature of these systems

The book ends with a commendable set of proposals for reducing the risks of catastrophic cyber damage, including greater focus worldwide on transparency and safety in the development of software. Not "move fast and break things" but "move slow and fix your sh*t"

Another disturbing recurring theme is that cyberweapons can cause much more devastation than their perpetrators expected, due to errors in their configuration. E.g WannaCry (N. Korea) and NotPetya (Russia) https://t.co/JmTmrrf3OC

The later chapters in "This Is How They Tell Me The World Ends" vividly highlight the dangerous 'boomerang' effects of cyberweapon. Components developed and stockpiled with a view to being used against other states, but which have fallen into the hands of determined adversaries https://t.co/3pSvOGfniQ

Evidence from psychopharmacology also highlights the key role of the reticular activating system (in the brainstem) with our sense of self and feeling #TheHiddenStream https://t.co/r2NM8PiIAt
In contrast, damage to just a small section (2 cubic mm) of the reticular activating system, in the brainstem, seems to prevent any sense of self #TheHiddenStream https://t.co/lT8SaH1LAN
Patients that lack a brain cortex entirely - who have only a brain stem and a cerebellum - can still display emotion and appear to be conscious #TheHiddenStream https://t.co/8BCuj8iOWb
However, case histories of people with severely damaged prefrontal lobes throw that theory in doubt. These patients seem to be every bit as self-conscious as the rest of us #TheHiddenStream

The generally accepted view, says @Mark_Solms, has been that the prefrontal lobes of the cortex contain a "global workspace" that somehow integrates sensory streams, giving rise to our sense of self #TheHiddenStream https://t.co/jvWMpp40Zb
@schulzb589 @Mark_Solms @Ri_Science Yes, that was a shocker. But it did grab the attention!
To understand the inner sense of self, we should look, not at the cortex, but at the brainstem, argues @Mark_Solms #TheHiddenSpring https://t.co/maV9PmvI6K

Some voters would like this system as it would allow them to vote 1. Patriots and 2. Republican. Others would like it as it would have allowed them to vote 1. Bernie Sanders and 2. Joe Biden. Yet others would vote 1. Transhumanist Party, 2. another party, etc
